intro: Alepidocline pochutlana, commonly known as the Mexican mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on the branches of various host trees. It belongs to the family Viscaraceae and is characterized by its evergreen foliage and small, white or yellowish flowers. The plant produces berries that are dispersed by birds, contributing to its spread within its native habitat. Its botanical structure includes a root system that attaches to the host plant, allowing it to extract water and nutrients. Alepidocline pochutlana is native to Mexico and is often found in tropical and subtropical regions.
